Question: Which cytoskeleton is associated with the desmosome?
Explanation:
Question
Which cytoskeleton is associated with the desmosome?

Correct answer: A — Intermediate filament

Core idea (exam focus)
Desmosomes (macula adherens) anchor intermediate filaments (keratin/desmin) via desmoplakin.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Actin is for adherens junctions; microtubules are not the primary anchoring element at desmosomes.

Why the other options are not
  • B: Desmosomes specifically link intermediate filaments, actin links to adherens junctions, microtubules are not junction anchors.
  • C: Desmosomes specifically link intermediate filaments, actin links to adherens junctions, microtubules are not junction anchors.
  • D: Desmosomes specifically link intermediate filaments, actin links to adherens junctions, microtubules are not junction anchors.
  • E: Desmosomes specifically link intermediate filaments, actin links to adherens junctions, microtubules are not junction anchors.

Exam gold (high-yield)

Question: Where else in the cell are localized the intermediate filaments, except in the cytosol?
Explanation:
Question
Where else in the cell are localized the intermediate filaments, except in the cytosol?

Correct answer: A — Nucleus

Core idea (exam focus)
Intermediate filaments are present in the nucleus as lamins forming the nuclear lamina.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • RER, lysosomes, peroxisomes, and Golgi are organelles, not IF locations.

Why the other options are not
  • B: Not consistent with the tested definition/mechanism.
  • C: Not consistent with the tested definition/mechanism.
  • D: Not consistent with the tested definition/mechanism.
  • E: Not consistent with the tested definition/mechanism.

Question: Which of the following statements is TRUE? The microtubules are built of:
Explanation:
Question
Which of the following statements is TRUE? The microtubules are built of:

Correct answer: A — 13 protofilaments

Core idea (exam focus)
Microtubules are hollow tubes of α/β-tubulin arranged in 13 protofilaments.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Keratin/vimentin/neurofilaments = intermediate filaments; microfilaments = actin.

Why the other options are not
  • B: Keratin/vimentin/neurofilaments are intermediate filaments; microfilaments are actin.
  • C: Keratin/vimentin/neurofilaments are intermediate filaments; microfilaments are actin.
  • D: Keratin/vimentin/neurofilaments are intermediate filaments; microfilaments are actin.
  • E: Keratin/vimentin/neurofilaments are intermediate filaments; microfilaments are actin.

Exam gold (high-yield)

Question: Which of the following answers is TRUE? A major function of the rough ER is:
Explanation:
Question
Which of the following answers is TRUE? A major function of the rough ER is:

Correct answer: A — Protein synthesis

Core idea (exam focus)
Rough ER has ribosomes, it synthesizes proteins destined for secretion, membranes, and lysosomes.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Lipid synthesis mainly occurs in smooth ER; carbohydrate/glycolipid processing is mainly Golgi/ER lumen modifications.

Why the other options are not
  • B: RER mainly synthesizes proteins; lipid synthesis is SER; 'all answers' is therefore incorrect.
  • C: RER mainly synthesizes proteins; lipid synthesis is SER; 'all answers' is therefore incorrect.
  • D: RER mainly synthesizes proteins; lipid synthesis is SER; 'all answers' is therefore incorrect.
  • E: RER mainly synthesizes proteins; lipid synthesis is SER; 'all answers' is therefore incorrect.

Explanation:
Question
The glycocalyx is composed of all of the following EXCEPT:

Correct answer: A — Lipoproteins

Core idea (exam focus)
Glycocalyx is a carbohydrate-rich coat: glycoproteins, proteoglycans, and glycolipids.

  • B: Glycocalyx is carbohydrate-rich, not generic lipoproteins; glycoproteins/proteoglycans/glycolipids are typical.
  • C: Glycocalyx is carbohydrate-rich, not generic lipoproteins; glycoproteins/proteoglycans/glycolipids are typical.

Question: Which cytoskeleton is associated with the focal adhesion?
Explanation:
Question
Which cytoskeleton is associated with the focal adhesion?

Correct answer: A — Actin filament

Core idea (exam focus)
Focal adhesions link ECM (via integrins) to actin stress fibers through talin/vinculin/paxillin.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Intermediate filaments anchor at hemidesmosomes; microtubules are not the primary linkage at focal adhesions.

Why the other options are not
  • B: Focal adhesions link integrins to actin stress fibers, not to intermediate filaments or microtubules.
  • C: Focal adhesions link integrins to actin stress fibers, not to intermediate filaments or microtubules.
  • D: Focal adhesions link integrins to actin stress fibers, not to intermediate filaments or microtubules.
  • E: Focal adhesions link integrins to actin stress fibers, not to intermediate filaments or microtubules.

OptionE: They play a role in blood coagulation

Correct answer: A — Promyelocyte

Granulopoiesis sequence: myeloblast → promyelocyte → myelocyte → metamyelocyte → band → segmented granulocyte.

  • Myelocyte is later; mature granulocytes are final stages.

  • C: This stage occurs later than myeloblast; the immediate next stage is promyelocyte.

OptionA: Diffusion through the matrix of the cartilage
Explanation:
Question
Chondrocytes receive nutrients via:

Correct answer: A — Diffusion through the matrix of the cartilage

Cartilage is avascular, chondrocytes rely on diffusion through the extracellular matrix from perichondrium/synovial fluid.

Why the other options are not
  • B: These belong to bone (Haversian/Volkmann/canaliculi) or are incorrect because cartilage is avascular.

Somatostatin (GHIH) is produced by hypothalamic neurons and inhibits GH/TSH release from adenohypophysis.

Why the other options are not

Explanation:
Question
Which one of the following proteins builds the reticular fibers in loose connective tissue?

Correct answer: A — Collagen type III

Core idea (exam focus)
Reticular fibers are composed of type III collagen, forming delicate supporting networks.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Type I = thick fibers; type IV = basal lamina; type II = cartilage; elastin = elastic fibers.

Why the other options are not
  • B: Reticular fibers are type III collagen; other collagen types/elastin correspond to different tissues/structures.
  • C: Reticular fibers are type III collagen; other collagen types/elastin correspond to different tissues/structures.
  • D: Reticular fibers are type III collagen; other collagen types/elastin correspond to different tissues/structures.

Question
Which of the following statements regarding the red muscle fibers is NOT correct?

Correct answer: A — They contract quickly

Core idea (exam focus)
Red (type I) fibers: slow-twitch, oxidative, rich in myoglobin and mitochondria, high lipid, relatively lower glycogen.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Fast contraction is typical of white (type II) fibers.

Why the other options are not
  • B: Red fibers are slow oxidative, the listed feature does not match type I physiology.
  • C: Red fibers are slow oxidative, the listed feature does not match type I physiology.
  • D: Red fibers are slow oxidative, the listed feature does not match type I physiology.

Correct answer: A — Extravasal

From ~3rd month, fetal hematopoiesis is predominantly hepatic (liver), classically described as extravascular (outside vessels) in sinusoids.

Question: Which of the following originate(s) from the paraxial mesoderm?
Explanation:
Question
Which of the following originate(s) from the paraxial mesoderm?

Correct answer: A — Dermis (skin)

Core idea (exam focus)
Paraxial mesoderm forms somites → dermatome (dermis), myotome (skeletal muscle), sclerotome (vertebrae).

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Nervous tissue = ectoderm; odontoblasts/cementoblasts = neural crest; cardiomyocytes = lateral plate mesoderm; smooth muscle mainly splanchnic mesoderm.

Why the other options are not
  • B: Paraxial mesoderm forms somites (dermis, skeletal muscle, vertebrae), other options belong to other germ layers.
  • C: Paraxial mesoderm forms somites (dermis, skeletal muscle, vertebrae), other options belong to other germ layers.
  • D: Paraxial mesoderm forms somites (dermis, skeletal muscle, vertebrae), other options belong to other germ layers.

Question: The intraembryonic lateral plate mesoderm generates which of the following?
Explanation:

Correct answer: A — Limb buds

Core idea (exam focus)
Lateral plate mesoderm (somatic layer) contributes to limb buds and body wall; splanchnic layer contributes to heart and smooth muscle of gut.

  • Epidermis/CNS = ectoderm; glandular epithelium = endoderm; notochord = axial (chordamesoderm).

  • B: Lateral plate mesoderm contributes to limbs/body wall, other listed tissues originate from ectoderm/endoderm/axial mesoderm.

Exam gold (high-yield)

Question: The second meiotic division during oogenesis begins:
OptionE: None of the answers is true
Explanation:
Question
The second meiotic division during oogenesis begins:

Correct answer: D — At the time of ovulation

Core idea (exam focus)
Primary oocytes are arrested in prophase I before birth. At ovulation, the secondary oocyte is arrested in metaphase II, i.e., meiosis II has begun.

Mechanism / reasoning
  • Completion occurs only after fertilization.

Why the other options are not
  • A: Meiosis II begins around ovulation in the secondary oocyte and arrests at metaphase II; other timings are incorrect.
  • B: Meiosis II begins around ovulation in the secondary oocyte and arrests at metaphase II; other timings are incorrect.
  • C: Meiosis II begins around ovulation in the secondary oocyte and arrests at metaphase II; other timings are incorrect.
  • E: Meiosis II begins around ovulation in the secondary oocyte and arrests at metaphase II; other timings are incorrect.
